raw_text:
'My memories of Marley...'
 
 To mark the 60th anniversary of the birth of reggae star Bob Marley, Rob Partridge - Marley's former head of press at Island Records - remembers the man behind the legend.
 
 Partridge worked with Marley from 1977 until the Jamaican musician's death in 1981.
 
 : "I joined Island Records in 1977 and the first week I was there I worked on his show at the Rainbow Theatre. It was one of the last dates he did in London."
 
 : The album Exodus came out in 1977 and that provided five hits and confirmed his global superstar status. "By 1979 he was the biggest touring attraction in the world. I remember going to see dates in Milan and Turin and they were enormous concerts."
 
 : Bob was one of the most mesmeric people I've ever had the privilege to work with. "He must have had an iron will to succeed. Bob was a very driven individual. You realised from the start there was a manifest destiny within him that he believed in. He didn't suffer fools gladly. At the risk of stating the obvious, he was an extraordinary song writer and his stage act was perhaps the greatest I've ever seen. I saw him many times."
 
 : "I recall in 1978 he came to the UK for Top of the Pops and a Daily Mirror journalist did a half-hour interview. It was interrupted to do a rehearsal. He came back into the dressing room to resume the interview but saw a World Cup match on TV.
 
 "He sat down in front of the TV and after 10 minutes it was obvious he wasn't going to move. That was the end of it. The Mirror had a very truncated interview. "The last time I saw him was in London in 1980. I arranged for him to play four days of football indoors in Fulham. "Bob was a good player. We are talking about Jamaican-style football. He was an attacking midfield player. His team assembled wherever his gigs were. We played in Brazil against some World Cup-winning players."
 
 : It was always a struggle for him to connect with Black America. Reggae did not correspond with disco in the 70s. But Bob in the 1990s became one of the great icons in America and the Third World. "In 1991, ten years after his death, he sold more records than at any time during his life. "We saw Black America taking Bob into their hearts for the first time."
 
 : "Bob, in worldwide terms, is the greatest music star there has ever been. If you went to Africa he would be recognised everywhere, in places John Lennon or Elvis wouldn't be. "No disrespect to the other artists but a case can be made for him as the greatest, the best and the most influential artist in popular music."
 
 : Well 1981 was to be the year he toured Africa with Stevie Wonder. He had only performed in Zimbabwe and Guinea before. "Of course the 1981 tour never happened, but the whole of Africa would have embraced him. We can't speculate but he was at the height of his powers and just 36 years old. I had no sense his career was going to go downhill."
 
 : "Bob was endlessly optimistic about the way Africa would turn out. He realised that nothing was perfect but he had total belief in the power of mankind. "I'm sure if he were alive today he would believe Africa would firstly become politically free and secondly be able to defeat the Aids epidemic."
 
 : "The final tune of his final album was Redemption Song - one of the most incredible classics of all time."
llama3.2:1b:
Here is a concise summary of the text:

Rob Partridge, former head of press at Island Records, remembers working with Bob Marley from 1977 to 1981.
He recalls their time together as some of the best shows in London, including an appearance on Top of the Pops and a Daily Mirror interview interrupted by a World Cup match.
Marley's success was marked by his ability to connect with diverse audiences globally.
In the 1990s, he became one of the most iconic artists in America and Africa.
Partridge credits Marley for his enduring influence on popular music and optimism about the potential of humanity.

Key events include:

* Worked on Marley's show at the Rainbow Theatre in London
* Released Exodus album in 1977, which provided five hits and global superstar status
* Saw many iconic performances with Marley
* Appeared on Top of the Pops and Daily Mirror interviews while touring Africa
* Played indoor football matches for Marley in Brazil against World Cup-winning players
llama3.2:3b: Rob Partridge worked with Bob Marley from 1977 until his death in 1981.
He recalls Marley's global superstardom, mesmeric stage presence, and driven personality.
Partridge also remembers challenges in connecting Marley with Black America during the 70s disco era, but notes that Marley became a cultural icon in America and Africa in the 1990s.
gemma2:2b: Bob Marley, a global reggae star who achieved fame in the 1970s, is remembered by Rob Partridge, his former press representative.
Partridge details his experience working with Marley during the singer's rise to international success and the impact Marley had on music and culture.
He highlights Marley's charisma, determination, songwriting talent, and stage presence.
The text also mentions Marley's struggles in connecting with Black America in the 1970s but later becoming a global icon in the 1990s.
The text ends by reflecting on Marley’s unfulfilled potential for African tours in 1981, as well as his optimistic outlook on Africa's future.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Bob Marley: Reggae legend in 1980s world.
He had a very successful career as a singer and performer, winning multiple Grammy Awards.
The 60th anniversary is a special occasion for him, so he's remembering his impact on the music industry.
His "exodus" from Island Records in 1977 marked his final visit to London.
Marley was known as a big star who toured the world and saw many famous people like world champions.
He worked with Bob Dylan, Stevie Wonder and other musicians.
Bob Marley's career continued after his death until he sold more records than any other musician in history.
He was admired by many artists from around the world for being one of the greatest music stars of all time.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Reggae legend Bob Marley's manager reflects on working with him from 1977 until his death in 1981.
He praises Marley's iron will, songwriting talent, and stage performance, highlighting his influence as a global icon even decades after his passing.
Marley struggled to connect with Black America but became one of the greatest icons in America during his later years.
The tour of Africa in 1981 would have been embraced by the continent, despite not happening due to health issues.
Redemption Song was described as an "incredible classic."
qwen2.5:3b: Rob Partridge remembers Bob Marley, recalling their collaboration from 1977 until Marley's death in 1981.
Partridge describes Marley as a global superstar with five hits on the Exodus album and a captivating stage presence.

He notes that despite facing challenges connecting with Black America during disco era, Marley became an icon in America and Africa posthumously, selling more records in the 1990s than during his lifetime.
Partridge recalls Marley's optimistic view of Africa and his intention to tour there when he had only performed in Zimbabwe and Guinea before.
He also mentions that Marley was the greatest music star worldwide and believes he would advocate for political freedom and AIDS awareness if alive today.
opencoder:1.5b:
My memories of Bob Marley from their 60th anniversary are as follows:

1.
Work Experience: Reggae star Bob Partridge, a former head of press at Island Records, worked with Marley until his Jamaican musician's death in 1981.
Album Exodus: The album was released in 1979 and provided 5 hits and confirmed his global superstar status.
He achieved this through concert success and the completion of an extraordinary project.
Band performance: Bob played an impressive number of dates in Milan and Turin, making them enormous concerts.
Messages from the album: Rob Partridge was a mesmerizing character behind the legend, inspiring him with his iron will to succeed and his passion for music.
Band Meetings: Bob met Black America through the 19en during which he became one of the greatest icons in America and the Third World.
Future of Bob: With regards to African performances, he had only performed in Zimbabwe and Guinea before; however, he continued to perform with Stevie Wonder on an upcoming tour in Africa.
Attractions: 1981 was a year marked by a switch from reggae to disco music, marking the end of Africa's reggae roots.
He toured with fellow artists like Elvis, John Lennon and the likes before settling into the present day.

Conclusion: Despite his career being filled with trials and tribulations, he remained the greatest artist in popular music, and if today's generations continue to dream of becoming true musicians, he would be too.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: Rob Partridge remembers Bob Marley from 1977 to 1981, working with him at Island Records.
He helped create the album Exodus in 1977, becoming a global superstar.
Bob was known for his energy and met a journalist interview cut short due to a TV match.
He moved to England for Top of the Pops and played football in London.
In 1991, he sold more records than anyone else.
He's often called a global star but faced challenges, including not performing in Zimbabwe for Stevie Wonder.
Despite his tough career, he is frequently referred to as one of the greatest stars in popular music.
tinyllama:1.1b: In celebration of Bob Marley's 60th anniversary, Rob Partridge remembers the man behind the legend.
Marley joined Island Records in 1977 and worked with them for five years before departing to form a successful solo career with hits like "Exodu" and "Redemption Song."
Partridge describes Marley's impact on reggae music, his meteoric rise from humble beginnings to global superstar status, his relentless drive, and how he influenced Black America.

The author recalls various aspects of Marley's personal life and work, including his 1981 tour in Africa with Stevie Wonder but ultimately unable to finish the tour due to health issues, the optimistic belief in the power of mankind, and the importance of Africa becoming politically free and defeating AIDS epidemic.
Partridge's fond memories of Marley include his mesmerizing stage performances and influence on reggae music.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The memories of Marley are many, but there is one incident that stands out for me and which has become a symbol of his life and career.
It happened on an extraordinary day in London in 1978: Marley was invited to the Top of the Pops interview by Daily Mirror journalist John McCullum.
At the time, Marley was touring with Island Records, but he had also just signed a deal with Warner Music.
It was during this rehearsal that he interrupted his interview to watch a World Cup match on TV.
As he sat down for the interview, it appeared that he wasn't going to move from his seat.
The journalist, desperate to finish the interview, tried repeatedly to get him up.
Marley remained seated, clearly unsatisfied with this situation.
It was a turning point in his career and a defining moment in our relationship.
He was always a visionary who saw beyond the limitations of what people believed were possible for him.
Despite facing many obstacles, he persevered and achieved incredible things in music, both on the global stage and within Jamaica's culture.
phi:2.7b: The article is about Bob Marley, a reggae star who died in 1991.

The author, Rob Partridge, reflects on his experience working with Marley at Island Records and recalls some of the highlights of their relationship, such as Marley's global success, his stage act, and his impact on Black America.
The author also expresses his admiration for Marley's optimism about Africa's future.
orca-mini:3b: The passage is about Rob Partridge, who worked with Bob Marley during his time at Island Records.
Partridge shares his memories of working with Marley and discusses his achievements and impact on popular music.
He also speculates about what might have been if Marley had not died so young.
hermes3:3b:
Summary of Bob Marley memories:
* Worked with Marley at Island Records from 1977.
* Exodus album (1977) confirmed global superstar status, huge tours by 1979.
* Reggae did not connect with disco in Black America, but Bob became icon there in 1990s.
* In worldwide terms, Bob is considered the greatest music star ever.
* Planned 1981 Africa tour with Stevie Wonder, never happened.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Rob Partridge, former head of press at Island Records for reggae star Bob Marley, reflects on his memories of working with Marley over a span of four years until his death in 1981.
Partridge recalls the release of Marley's album Exodus in 1977, which propelled Marley to global superstardom and saw him become the biggest touring attraction in the world.
He shares anecdotes about Marley's determination, iron will to succeed, and exceptional songwriting skills.
Partridge also discusses Marley's struggle to connect with Black America but his eventual rise as a great icon in America and the Third World.
The text concludes by noting that Marley is widely regarded as the greatest music star in popular history, having an enduring impact on African audiences.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Rob Partridge, Bob Marley's former head of press at Island Records, reflects on his time working with the reggae legend from 1977 until his death in 1981.
He recalls Marley's rise to global superstardom, particularly after the release of *Exodus* in 1977, and his immense stage presence.
Partridge describes Marley as a driven and charismatic individual with a strong sense of destiny.
He shares anecdotes, including Marley's passion for football and a truncated interview due to his love for the World Cup.
Despite struggling to connect with Black America during his lifetime, Marley became an icon in the 1990s, selling more records posthumously than ever before.
Partridge argues that Marley is the greatest and most influential music star, recognized worldwide, even in places where other legends like John Lennon or Elvis Presley might not be.
He reflects on Marley's unfulfilled plans to tour Africa in 1981 and his optimism about the continent's future.
He concludes by highlighting *Redemption Song* as one of Marley's most powerful classics.
stablelm2:1.6b: Rob Partridge, former head of press at Island Records, reminisces about Bob Marley.
He worked with Marley from 1977 until his death in 1981.
Marley became a global superstar after the release of album Exodus, which had five hits.
He was also the biggest touring attraction in the world during his time.
Despite not being well-received by some African audiences due to reggae not aligning with disco, Bob Marley became an icon in America and the Third World.
In 1981, ten years after his death, he sold more records than at any other time in his life.
Partridge believes Bob is the greatest music star there has ever been, surpassing even John Lennon or Elvis.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Bob Marley, a reggae icon, was a driven and mesmerizing figure in the music industry.
His career took off with the 1977 release of "Exodus," which featured five hits and solidified his global status as a superstar.
Partridge, Marley's former head of press at Island Records from 1977 until his death in 1981, recalls his interactions with Marley during tours in Europe and the UK, where he was a massive draw.
Marley's iron will, songwriting prowess, and captivating stage performances were evident from the start.
Despite struggles in connecting with Black America due to the contrasting genres of reggae and disco in the 1970s, he gained significant influence in America and the Third World by the late 1980s.
In 1991, ten years post-death, Marley sold more records than ever before, marking Black America's embrace of his music.

Partridge praised Marley as the greatest music star in history, stating that he would be recognized everywhere in Africa, a continent where other legendary artists like John Lennon and Elvis were not.

In 1981, Marley was set to tour Africa with Stevie Wonder; Partridge believed he would have been a transformative figure on the continent, potentially addressing political freedom and the Aids epidemic.
Marley's final album, released in 1980, included "Redemption Song," considered one of his most remarkable compositions.
Partridge described him as endlessly optimistic about Africa's potential for progress, particularly in overcoming political and health challenges.
